notes.div: Special sections of ENGL 101 may be devoted to literature by and about groups of Americans.

description.div: Beginning writing as inquiry using literary texts as resources for writing and the rhetorically-based concepts for reading and writing. Special sections may be devoted to literature by and about groups of Americans. A. African American Literature B. Chicano Literature D. Native American Literature

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

description.div: Intensive writing. Writing and critical reading practices. Develop writing projects for multiple purposes and audiences.

prerequisite.div: Permission.

notes.div: ENGL 140 does not satisfy the College of Arts and Sciences Distribution Requirements. No more than 6 credit hours of ENGL 140, ENGL 141, and ENGL 142 can be counted toward the degree.

description.div: Writing and grammar in academic contexts for international students.

prerequisite.div: Permission.

notes.div: ENGL 141 does not satisfy the College of Arts and Sciences Distribution Requirements. No more than 6 credit hours of ENGL 140, ENGL 141, and ENGL 142 can be counted toward the degree.

description.div: Reading comprehension in academic contexts for international students.

course.title: Advanced Academic Listening and Speaking Skills

prerequisite.div: Permission.

notes.div: ENGL 142 does not satisfy the College of Arts and Sciences Distribution Requirements. No more than 6 credit hours of ENGL 140, ENGL 141, and ENGL 142 can be counted toward the degree.

description.div: Advanced academic listening and speaking skills in academic conexts for international students.

notes.div: ENGL 150 is open to Freshman and Sophomores only.

description.div: Study and practice of writing using such rhetorical concepts as purpose, audience, genre, cultural context and style to develop strategies for writing, thinking and research.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation. ENGL 150H is open to Freshman and Sophomores only.

description.div: Intensive writing. Writing as a tool for inquiry and research. Develop writing projects for multiple purposes and audiences.

notes.div: ENGL 151 is open to Freshman and Sophomores only.

description.div: Intensive writing. Writing as a tool for argument. Develop writing projects for multiple purposes and audiences.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

description.div: Intensive writing. Writing as a tool for argument. Develop writing projects for multiple purposes and audiences.

notes.div: Does not satisfy Freshman English(composition) requirement.

description.div: General introduction for beginning students to the understanding and appreciation of the principal forms of literature: poetry, drama, and fiction.

prerequisite.div: Permission.

notes.div: Does not satisfy arts and sciences communication requirement.

description.div: Speaking and writing in academic contexts for international students.

prerequisite.div: Permission.

notes.div: Does not satisfy arts and sciences communication requirement.

description.div: Writing course for international students focusing on essay development and organization.

prerequisite.div: Permission.

notes.div: ENGL 188 is open to freshmen or sophomores only.

description.div: Advanced academic writing and speaking for international students.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

notes.div: University Honors Seminar 189H is required of all students in the University Honors Program.

description.div: Topics vary.

prerequisite.div: Permission.

notes.div: Required of English majors; recommended for minors.

description.div: The issues, perspectives, and methods of the discipline. The relationships among authors, texts, audiences, and contexts. Practice in imaginative and analytical approaches.
Introduction to the understanding and appreciation of the major dramatic genres-tragedy, comedy, and tragicomedy-in various historical periods.
Introduction to reading poetry. Emphasizes approaches to reading poems, analysis of themes and forms, and enjoyment of poetry as a genre.
Selected readings in the novel and short story, mainly American, British, and European, from 1900 to the present.
Nonfiction film genre from the 1890s to the present, highlighting the major events that have significantly affected it, its cinematic techniques, and its social context. Weekly film screenings.
Introduction to groups of literary works of various types from various periods and countries, studied in the context of a significant issue or concept.
Representations of illness and health as states of the body in a variety of literary texts.

Introduction to medieval literature and culture via the legends and romances of King Arthur and The Matter of Britain. Translations that were originally in Latin, Welsh, and French as well as English. The questions of ethnicity raised by the idea of an ancient Celtic Britain.
Literary works written in response to war, conflict, and peace.
Imaginative works drawn from literature and film. The ways in which different genres or media are used to tell stories and record lived experiences.

Introduction to writers and literary works associated with a particular place that would typically be defined by geographic factors rather than political boundaries and will vary from course to course, but will regularly include the North American Great Plains.

course.title: Introduction to Lesbian and Gay Literature

description.div: Introduction to variety of works by lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender writers. Literary, significant cultural, social, and historical issues and themes.
Historical survey from 1880 to the present, dealing with the major directors, films, genres, and critical theories which have shaped films in the twentieth century. Weekly film screenings.
Introduction to English literature written by women, studies in the cultural, social, and/or historical contexts.

notes.div: May not be offered every year.

description.div: Selected works of literature originally addressed primarily to children which have attracted adult attention to their artistry and themes.

Various film genres, such as Gothic, the Western, and film noir, from their inception in the early 1900s to the present day. Variations (such as 219A, Film Noir) may concentrate on a particular genre. Weekly film screenings.

Language as a system of arbitrary symbols for human communication. Pragmatics, semantics, syntax, morphology, phonology, language variation, first and second language acquisition, written language, language processing and the neurology of language.
Major British writers from Beowulf to the end of the eighteenth century. Attention given to historical background.
Introductory study of a representative sample of Shakespeare's works. Some films of dramatic performances may be shown.
Major works by British authors of the Romantic and Victorian periods and of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries.

course.title: The Jewish Idea in Modern Literature

description.div: Introduction to the literary and historical context of Jewish cultural life as expressed in modern works of literature in translation and cinema by Jewish intellectuals.

notes.div: Open to all undergraduates

description.div: Through the study of masterpieces read in translation, explores the ideas and motifs that define the major literary expressions of the human experience. Includes the rebel, love, madness, representations of gender, the quest, childhood.

notes.div: May be repeated once for credit with a different topic.

description.div: Films of one director or a small group of directors. Weekly film screenings.
History and criticism of international women film directors.
English translations of the great works of Greek literature which familiarizes the student with the uniquely rich and influential world of Classical Greece.
English translations of the great works of Latin literature, which familiarize the student with the uniquely rich and influential world of Classical Rome.
Representative African American works, primarily twentieth century, of various genres, studied in their social and historical contexts.

Representative literary works by African writers, mainly in the English language, but with a sampling of works translated from other languages, from the twentieth century, and presented in their social, historical and social contexts.

notes.div: May not be offered every year.

description.div: Representative works of various types, primarily twentieth century, studied in their social and historical contexts.

notes.div: Course not taught every year.

description.div: History and multi-generic variety of African-Caribbean literature written in English.

notes.div: Course not taught every year.

description.div: Representative early African American works of various genres, studied in their social and historical contexts, from the oral tradition to the Harlem Renaissance.

course.title: Introduction to Asian American Literature and Culture

description.div: Introduction to twentieth-century Asian American literature and relevant historical and cultural background.
Introduction to literature by and about the American Indian covering early and recent periods.
Introduction to literature by and about Mexican-Americans in its cultural and historical context.
Twentieth century novels and short stories by major Jewish-American authors.
Representative writings by American Indian women in their social and historical contexts.
Introduction to the writing of poetry, fiction, and creative nonfiction. Writing, the development of the craft and technique, and analytical reading skills.
Introduction to the writing of fiction. Writing, analysis of craft, technique, and reading skills.
Introduction to the writing of poetry. Emphasis on student writing within a context of theory and criticism.

notes.div: ENGL/WMNS 253A may not be offered every year.

description.div: Introduction to the writing of poetry. Emphasis on student writing with special focus on reading women poets and on issues that concern women writers.
Extended writing and its uses in and by various communities.

Reading and analysis of published autobiographical writing and practice in recalling, researching, and writing autobiographical material. [258x]. Special Topics in Writing (2 cr) Prereq: 6 hrs freshman English. Independent study course for intermediate students in the study and practice of composition.

prerequisite.div: 6 hrs freshman English.

description.div: Independent study course for intermediate students in the study and practice of composition.
Introduction to the basics of screenplay writing from the conception of an idea through its realization in a screenplay written in the master scene format.
Major authors, themes, and intellectual trends in American literature from the beginnings to 1865. Works from the Colonial, Early National, and Romantic periods.
Major authors, themes, and intellectual trends in American literature from 1865 to the present. Works from the Realist, Modernist, and Contemporary periods.

notes.div: May be repeated once for credit with a different topic.

description.div: Intensive examination of artistic movements and major directors in an important historic period of film. Examples: Russian film of the '20s, the French New Wave, Hollywood in the '30s. Weekly film screenings.
Nature and function of literary/critical theory in the study of literary texts. Selected approaches and is not intended as a general survey.
Nature and function of rhetorical theory as applied to English Studies. Selected important ancient and modern rhetorical theories and is not intended as a general historical survey.

notes.div: ENGL 278 requires contributing to an ongoing web-based project.

description.div: Introduction to the variety of rationales, technologies, and materials that commonly inform electronic projects in the humanities. Definitions of digital research, various theoretical and methodological approaches, and the implications for the academy, publishers, classrooms, and libraries.
Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of both thematic and formal/technical relationships between works of literature and music, visual arts, theatre, and the plastic and spatial arts.

prerequisite.div: Sophomore standing and at least 3 cr in literature in English or modern languages.

notes.div: Course not taught every year.

description.div: Introduction to the methods and materials of scholarly comparison of literatures of different languages, cultures, historical periods, and genres.

prerequisite.div: Permission.

description.div: Major playwrights and dramatic movements, such as realism, naturalism, expressionism, "epic theater," and theater of the absurd, from Ibsen to the present.

div.span: Introductory survey of major authors and movements in English-language poetry during the modernist period of the early twentieth century

description.div: Major trends and authors of British and American poetry since 1960.
Major authors, themes, and intellectual trends in contemporary poetry.
Introduction to the historical context, criticism, and interpretation of short stories.
Readings in the British novel from its beginning to 1900. Examples: works by Defoe, Fielding, Austen, Dickens, Eliot, Hardy.

prerequisite.div: Permission.

notes.div: Course not taught every year.

description.div: Romantic movement in literature and its relation to political and economic revolutions in England, France, and America.

notes.div: ENGL/WMNS 315A may not be offered every year.

description.div: Historical survey of womens writings in English.
Relation between women's roles and popular images in the media, including romances, television shows, science fiction, and magazines, with attention to their historical development.
Various issues, trends, and traditions concerning the literary representation of the natural environment.

notes.div: A course in linguistic analysis of the structure of English language and not a course in the rules of English grammar and composition.

description.div: Aims, methods, and results of descriptive analysis of contemporary English, with emphasis on the syntax of American English.
How language is used in the media, education, and politics. Bilingualism, speech style, kinesics, pragmatics, orality and literacy, dialects, gender and applied sociolinguistics.
The works of an author or small group of authors, usually in historical and biographical context.

notes.div: ENGL 330A requires weekly film screenings.

description.div: Strategies employed in adapting the plays of William Shakespeare for film and video. Integration of critical approaches from the perspectives of cultural studies, film, literature, and theatre.

Three major figures of English literature: Geoffrey Chaucer, William Shakespeare, and John Milton. How changes in society and in the media of production (oral presentation, manuscripts, public and private stages, and print) affected each writer’s sense of his audience and his craft. These writers in relation to each other: their common themes, shared sources, and awareness of – and challenges to – literary predecessors.

notes.div: ENGL 331 may not be offered every year.

description.div: The works of an author or small group of authors, usually in historical and biographical context.
Intensive study of the works of an author or small group of authors, usually in historical and biographical context.

notes.div: ENGL 333 may not be offered every year.

description.div: The works of an author or small group of authors, usually in historical and biographical context.

notes.div: ENGL 333A may not be offered every year.

description.div: Cather's work as an entry into the humanities, multiple texts, and their contexts. Interdisciplinary approach.
American literary traditions or movements through multiple genres from a variety of theoretical, socio-historical, and cultural approaches.
Greek and Roman literary works emphasizing their influence on English and American literature.
Introduction to the literary analysis of the Hebrew and Christian Scriptures with emphasis on their influence on British and American literature.

notes.div: May be repeated once for credit with a different topic.

description.div: Construction of ethnic identies in film and TV and the impact of such images on American culture.
Literature of the plains in its ethnic cultural contexts, both in relation to the arts and humanities, and to religion, anthropology, history and geography.

notes.div: May be repeated once for credit with a different topic.

description.div: Films produced in one country, seen in their aesthetic and historical context. Examples: Italian cinema since World War II, Japanese cinema, Australian cinema.
Study and practice of the writing of fiction for intermediate students with previous fiction writing experience.
Study and practice of the writing of poetry for intermediate students with previous poetry writing experience.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs writing course at the 200 level or above.

description.div: Extended practice in writing through the study of literacy--situating students' own literacy histories, exploring larger public debates about literacy, and researching the relationships between language, power, identity and authority.

prerequisite.div: Admission to Teacher Education Program in the College of Education and Human Sciences.

description.div: Recent research on literacy development and writing processes. Extended reflection and some application of theory to students' experiences with writing instruction and their own goals as K-12 teachers.
Major English works, in the original language and in translation, from Beowulf to the late Middle Ages, with a focus on Chaucer.
Representative works in various genres written in England during the sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries which reflect major themes and intellectual trends of the Renaissance period.

course.title: Introduction to Restoration and Eighteenth-Century Literature

description.div: Major English writers-such as Dryden, Pope, Swift, Johnson-seen in the literary, historical, and intellectual context of the period 1660-1800.
Poetry and prose of the principal British authors of the Romantic and Victorian periods.

notes.div: May be repeated once for credit with a different topic.

description.div: Study of particular film theories and methods of applied criticism for the intermediate or advanced student with previous film study experience. Weekly film screenings.
Study of rhetoric as it functions in social and political contexts.

prerequisite.div: Admission to Teacher Education Program in the College of Education and Human Sciences.

description.div: Recent research on literacy development and reading processes. Extended reflection and some application of theory to students' experiences with reading instruction and their own goals as K-12 teachers.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing or permission.

description.div: English translation of the Greek and Roman novel.

prerequisite.div: Permission.
Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.
Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Particular historical periods or other groupings of dramas. The relation of the writers both to one another and to the aesthetic and intellectual climate of their times. Examples: drama survey, modern drama, American drama, and Shakespeare's contemporaries in drama.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: Overview of contemporary gay and lesbian drama.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Epic, Renaissance, Romantic, Victorian, American, and contemporary poetry.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Survey of British poetry, 1780-1835. The traditional major authors and some of the many other poets whose works were popular and influential. The social, historical, and cultural context.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: The narrative genre of the short story, as represented by stories from American authors of the nineteenth century to the present day.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Fiction, primarily novels, in particular historical periods or other groupings. The relation of the writers both to one another and to the aesthetic and intellectual climate of their time.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: The most popular and influential literary genre in the nineteenth century, the novel, through representative Romantic, Victorian, and "fin de siecle" (end of century) works.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Survey of British fiction (primarily novels), 1780-1850. Major and minor authors whose works illustrate the tastes and trends of British fiction in the early modern period. The literary, social, and cultural context.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Key British and American novels and short stories from about 1910 to 1950. Modernism as a literary and cultural practice. Modernism's interpretation of the revolutionary changes in culture and society in the first half of the twentieth century. The relation between modernism and postmodernism.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: Survey of modern Canadian novels and short stories from 1920 to the present plus some other genres. The historical and cultural context.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Survey of novels written by a variety of men and women of diverse backgrounds in the United States from the late eighteenth century to 1900.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Survey of novels written by a variety of men and women of diverse backgrounds in the United States from 1900 to the present day.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: History and theory of the concept of genre as exemplified in literary works in various forms: comedy, tragedy, and satire.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: A literary movement (national or transnational), the development of a genre, or the intellectual and historical origins of an idea, as reflected in literature. May include the literature of abolition, alternative Romanticisms, literary modernism, the literature of Civil Rights, postmodernism, and/or the avant garde movement.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: Various forms of literature seen in the historical, cultural, and aesthetic context of the North American Great Plains.

notes.div: May be repeated once for credit with a different topic.

description.div: Study of specific critical and historical film theory and approaches to film history using more difficult texts (both as films and as readings) for the students, to create an intense immersion into more complex films and critical readings.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: A particular historical or other groups of literature by and about women, seen in their aesthetic and intellectual context.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: Selected women writers from the twentieth and twenty-first century.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: The shift from printed to digital texts and its implications for the nature of meaning and research in the humanities. Practice in digitally encoding texts and analysis of representative electronic projects dedicated to a variety of authors and genres.
Introduction for advanced students to the history and methods of linguistics, to the theory of language, and to applications of linguistics in a variety of fields and disciplines.
Historical development of contemporary English with particular attention to its Old and Middle English background.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: Practical application of the principles of linguistics. Examples: TESOL Theory and Practice, Second Language Composition Theory and Practice, Introduction to First and Second Language Acquisition, Teaching of Grammar.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Old English. Read and understand literary texts of the period in their historical context.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: The works of a particular major author, such as Chaucer, Shakespeare, or Milton situated within literary, historical, biographical, and critical context.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: How performance-based strategies can help in understanding and in teaching Shakespeare’s plays. The historical and contemporary stage practices, the performance history of these plays, and recent criticism that engages with the insights of both Performance Theory and Semiotics.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: The works of a particular major author seen in a wide critical context.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Extensive study in the works of a particular major author seen in a wide critical context.

notes.div: May be repeated once for credit with a different topic.

description.div: Intensive study of the films of one director or a small group of directors, with emphasis on an auteur approach. Weekly film screenings.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing or permission.

description.div: Greek and Roman tragedy and comedy in translation.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: Works of writers with connections to one or more American ethnic communities, seen in their historical, intellectual, and cultural context. Survey of ethnic literature.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: African American poetry, fiction, and/or non-fiction prose.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: Native American poetry, fiction, and/or non-fiction prose. Critical theory and cultural criticism.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: African and African-American poetry, fiction, and/or non-fiction prose.

prerequisite.div: ENGL 252 or permission.

description.div: For advanced students with previous experience in fiction writing. Longer projects in fiction writing.

prerequisite.div: ENGL 252 or 253.

description.div: Advanced (workshop) course for creative writers; emphasis on memoirs, personal essays, other forms of literary non-fiction.

prerequisite.div: ENGL 253 or permission.

description.div: For advanced students with previous experience in poetry writing.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs English composition above the English 200 level.

description.div: Advanced writing workshop in which experienced writers develop extended projects in writing, analyze their own and other's writing processes, and read widely in genres related to their projects.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Theoretical approaches to writing instruction and to the field of composition and rhetoric.
Development of screenplays.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: The various genres and movements of Medieval English literature and their cultural context.

course.title: Ideas of Ethnicity in Medieval Literature

description.div: Medieval literary texts that involve encounters between different religions and cultures. Readings from chronicles, romances, debates and epics.
Extensive study of major authors and works of the sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries with particular attention to the development of poetic and prose literary forms and their cultural context.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Major writers and critical issues of the period. Emphasis on poetry and nonfiction prose.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Poetry and prose of the Romantic and Victorian periods. Their intellectual and cultural context.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: Theory of literary periods and movements and the causes for change among them. Periods, movements, and readings are taken from British literature from about 1475 to about 1950.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

description.div: History, analysis and application of a variety of trends in literary criticism and critical theory.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

notes.div: ENGL 475/875 may not be offered every year.

description.div: Rhetoric and rhetorical theory in relation to literature, composition, and language.

course.title: Rhetorical Theory: Rhetoric of Women Writers

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: Rhetoric and rhetorical theory of women writers and speakers and its implications for literature, composition, literacy, feminist theory, and women's and gender studies.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: The shift from printed to digital texts and its implications for the nature of meaning and research in the humanities. Practice in digitally encoding texts and analysis of representative electronic projects dedicated to a variety of authors and genres.

course.title: Writing Theory and Practice for Consultants

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; two courses in ENGL above 199.

notes.div: Successful completion of ENGL 480/880 is required to intern or work as a consultant in UNL's Writing Assistance Center.

description.div: Introduction to issues and scholarship in teaching writing and working as a writing consultant.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

notes.div: ENGL 482/882 may include a literacy and/or writing internship in a community or workplace setting.

description.div: Literacy theory and its application in school, community, and workplace environments.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing.

notes.div: Individual projects.

description.div: Integration and application of skills and knowledge gained in courses taken for the English major. Development of these skills and knowledge toward life after graduation.
The relationship between significant medieval theologies and primary medieval poets and prose masters.

prerequisite.div: Permission.
Permission.
Senior standing.
